Na+occlusion seems to occur at a stage of the ATP hydrolysis cycle that is different from that which occludes K+, suggesting that occlusions of the two cations are mutually exclusive events. In the present study we expand the information about the Na+/K+-ATPase reaction, using the congener86Rb+ as a probe for K+ and performing direct measurements of the steady-state concentration levels of the intermediates containing occluded Rb+(Rbocc). In these experiments Rbocc was formed through the so-called physiological route, i.e. during the turnover of the Na+/K+-ATPase. In this condition K+ enters the enzyme presumably from the extracellular side to activate the catalysis of the hydrolysis of ATP (16Blostein R. Chu L. J. Biol. Chem. 1977; 252: 3035-3043Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Brief reports of measurements of this type of occlusion have been given by Glynn and Richards (4Glynn I.M. Richards D.E. J. The method is used during both steady-state turnover and in transient state experiments with the Na+/K+-pump. With the same enzyme preparations and under the same experimental conditions, we have also measured the steady-state ATPase activity, v t, and the rate coefficient, k deocc, for deocclusion of Rb+ from Rbocc. These can be analyzed as part of the Albers-Post model; a simplified version is shown in Fig.1. The results presented here show that the kinetics of the species containing occluded Rb+, i.e. E occ and E occATP, could be quantitatively described by the scheme in Fig. 1. We showed that the intermediates holding occluded Rb+ were only kinetically obligatory for the ATPase reaction at saturating concentrations of Rb+. We found, however, that even at concentrations of Rb+ that were sufficiently high as to drive the reaction totally away from the pathway that generates Na+-ATPase activity, a significant part of the hydrolysis bypassed the occluded forms. We show that a possible reason for this is that the phosphoenzyme containing only one Rb+(E 2PRb) dephosphorylates, without leading to occlusion of Rb+, with a rate coefficient whose value lies between those for dephosphorylation of E 2P andE 2PRb2. At this point, it seems convenient to include the theoretical grounds that underlie the experiments in which we tested whether the enzyme species containing occluded Rb+ are obligatory intermediates in the reaction cycle. To illustrate this, let us take the elementary reaction A↔ B in Scheme FSI as one of the steps of the enzyme reaction. The possibility that the step A ↔ B can be bypassed with the rate v other during the overall reaction is important for the argument to follow, whereas the order of addition of substrate(s) and the release of product(s) are not. If n pathways participate in the A ↔B transition, then in steady state the overall rate (v t) of the reaction catalyzed by the enzyme can be written as Equation 1. vt=∑i=1nkf,i[Ai]−∑i=1nkb,i[Bi]+votherEquation 1 where A i and B i are each of the n states of A and B, andk f,i and k b,i are the rate constants for their transitions. Equations Equation 1, Equation 2, Equation 3 provide a criterion to test if a family of intermediates (here, the A is) are obligatory participants of the enzyme reaction. If this were the case, thenv other would be 0 and the ratiov t/[A] would be equal to the rate coefficient for the reaction A → B. The present paper investigates the role of occluded Rb+ (acting as a congener of K+) in the reaction mechanism of Na+/K+-ATPase. Our fast quenching procedure with a time resolution of a few milliseconds has allowed us to determine quantitatively the concentration of occluded Rb+ (Rbocc) formed via the physiological route, that is by the Rb+-activated dephosphorylation of the phosphoenzyme E 2P. We have used the procedure to measure the steady-state level of Rbocc and the rate of deocclusion of Rb+ at 25 °C. We compared these measurements with estimations of steady-state Na+/Rb+-ATPase activity carried out in parallel experiments under exactly the same reaction conditions. To complete the information, we also measured the Na+-ATPase activity in steady state. In all the experiments, [NaCl] was 150 mm, [free Mg2+] was 0.5 mm, and the pH was kept at 7.4 with 20 mm imidazole HCl. The concentrations of Rb+ and ATP depended on each experiment and are given in the legend of each figure. The results were analyzed using the scheme in Fig. 1, which shows in more detail that part of the Albers-Post model involved in the formation and breakdown of the intermediates of the Na+/K+-ATPase that are supposed to hold occluded Rb+. As it is clear from the inspection of Fig. 1, the amount of enzyme containing occluded Rb+(E occ and E occATP) is a function of the concentrations of Rb+ and ATP. The effect of ATP is 2-fold since the nucleotide not only provides the phosphate of the phosphoenzyme intermediates, but it also accelerates deocclusion by binding to E occ. Chaperonin GroEL, consisting of two seven-subunit rings stacked back-to-back, is disassembled by interaction of 4,4′-dithiodipyridine (DTP) with Cys<sup>458</sup> located close to the intersubunit contacts within and between the rings. The thiol group of Cys<sup>458</sup> is inaccessible to the probe being buried into the pocket locked by segment Asn<sup>475</sup>–Asn<sup>487</sup>. Flexibility of this segment is proposed to induce the "open" state of the pocket and accommodate the bulky probe inside so that the consequential irreversible shifts in the pocket constituents disassemble GroEL. This scheme is supported by the finding that DTP-induced disassembly of GroEL is facilitated by ATP, which specifically stimulates a local shift of the segment Asn<sup>475</sup>–Asn<sup>487</sup> into solution.

To determine the catalytic role of Gln190, a member of the highly conserved LPQG motif in Moloney murine leukemia virus reverse transcriptase, we carried out site-directed mutagenesis of this residue to generate Q190N and Q190A. Both mutant proteins exhibited a significant loss in their polymerase and pyrophosphorolysis activities with a more pronounced effect noted with the Gln → Asn substitution. The catalytic efficiencies of the mutants exhibited a 40–70-fold reduction with poly(rC) and poly(dC) templates in the presence of Mg2+ and a 10–20-fold reduction with poly(rA) template in the presence of Mn2+. Interestingly, the K m for NTP exhibited only a moderate 3–10-fold increase irrespective of the template-primer and the metal ion. Photoaffinity labeling of both the mutant and the WT enzymes exhibited an identical affinity for RNA·DNA and DNA·DNA template-primers. However, unlike the WT enzyme, the mutant enzymes exhibited a significantly reduced ability to catalyze the nucleotidyltransferase reaction on the covalently immobilized template-primer. An examination of the rate constants for the first and the second nucleotide for the mutant enzymes indicated dissimilar rates, indicating that Gln190 may be involved in a rate-limiting, conformational change step both before and after the phosphodiester bond formation. Furthermore, the processivity of DNA synthesis by the mutant enzymes was decreased severely, which may result from the lower catalytic efficiency as well as translocation defect. To determine the catalytic role of Gln190, a member of the highly conserved LPQG motif in Moloney murine leukemia virus reverse transcriptase, we carried out site-directed mutagenesis of this residue to generate Q190N and Q190A. Both mutant proteins exhibited a significant loss in their polymerase and pyrophosphorolysis activities with a more pronounced effect noted with the Gln → Asn substitution. The catalytic efficiencies of the mutants exhibited a 40–70-fold reduction with poly(rC) and poly(dC) templates in the presence of Mg2+ and a 10–20-fold reduction with poly(rA) template in the presence of Mn2+. Interestingly, the K m for NTP exhibited only a moderate 3–10-fold increase irrespective of the template-primer and the metal ion. Photoaffinity labeling of both the mutant and the WT enzymes exhibited an identical affinity for RNA·DNA and DNA·DNA template-primers. However, unlike the WT enzyme, the mutant enzymes exhibited a significantly reduced ability to catalyze the nucleotidyltransferase reaction on the covalently immobilized template-primer. An examination of the rate constants for the first and the second nucleotide for the mutant enzymes indicated dissimilar rates, indicating that Gln190 may be involved in a rate-limiting, conformational change step both before and after the phosphodiester bond formation. Furthermore, the processivity of DNA synthesis by the mutant enzymes was decreased severely, which may result from the lower catalytic efficiency as well as translocation defect. The recombinant protein representing the WT MuLV RT and its two Gln190 mutant derivatives were purified from cell extracts using metal affinity chromatography as described under “Experimental Procedures.” The mutant enzymes exhibited a purity of greater than 95%. The level of their expression, their solubility, and chromatographic characteristics were identical with those of the WT enzyme. We performed far-UV CD analysis of the WT and mutant enzymes and observed nearly identical spectra for both species (Fig.2 A). This observation indicates that no significant change in the secondary structure of the mutant enzymes had occurred. In addition, we found that both mutants and the WT MuLV RT have nearly identical RNase H activity (Fig.2 B). These results suggest that the substitution at position Gln190 has not caused any significant change in the overall protein structure. Furthermore, results also indicate that Gln190 is not required in the catalysis of RNase H activity; hence alterations in the polymerase function of the mutants described appear to reflect the absence of glutamine side chain at position 190 in MuLV RT. To determine the reasons for the loss of activity by mutant enzymes, we first examined the steady-state kinetic parameters, i.e. k cat for the polymerase reaction andK m for dNTP utilization for both the mutant and the WT proteins. Homopolymeric template-primers, poly(rA)·(dT)18, poly(rC)·(dG)18, and poly(dC)·(dG)18, were used in these studies. Saturating concentrations of template-primer were used to mimic the first-order conditions for dNTP substrates. The rates of incorporation of α-32P- or 3H-labeled dNTP into the product with increasing concentrations of dNTP were measured, and thek cat for the polymerase reaction andK m for dNTP utilization were determined by Eadie-Hofstee plots from the rate data (TableI). Results show that substitution of Gln190 by both Ala and Asn caused about a 20-fold decrease in k cat and a 3-fold increase in theK m for dGTP with poly(dC)·(dG)18. In contrast, with poly(rC)·(dG)18, the decrease ink cat was less severe (5–9-fold), but a significant increase in K m (5–7-fold) was observed, suggesting that subtle differences exist in the participation of Gln190 in the catalytic reaction directed by the DNA or RNA template. However, the increase in K m for dNTP alone does not account for the significant loss of catalytic efficiency (k cat/K m) noted with both Q190N and Q190A, suggesting that the participation of Gln190 may be at a step beyond that of substrate binding, with Mg2+ as the divalent cation in the polymerase reaction. In the presence of Mn2+ as an effective metal cofactor, a significant increase (∼10-fold) in theK m for TTP with poly(rA)·(dT)18 was found for the Q190N mutant. Interestingly, both mutants exhibited only a marginal 2–4-fold decrease in k cat. This suggests that Gln190 may participate in substrate binding in the presence of Mn2+. To explore the role of Gln190 in the binding of template-primer, we carried out UV-mediated cross-linking of the WT and the mutant enzymes to various radiolabeled template-primers. We expected that a possible defect in the binding of the template-primer, either DNA or RNA, by the mutant enzymes would result in the reduction in the cross-linking of all or some template-primers. For this experiment, we utilized six different template-primers as follows. Four of them were constituted by synthetic 26/18-mer DNAs containing an azidophenacyl group at specific nucleotide positions either in the template or primer strand (see Fig. 1); their cross-linking to the enzyme was carried out at 312 nm. The two other template primers were the poly(rA)·(dT)18 and the 37-mer DNA, which were cross-linked at 254 nm (21Pandey V.N. Kaushik N. Modak M.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 21828-21834Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). All cross-linked species were resolved on 8% SDS-polyacrylamide gel followed by autoradiography. Both Q190N and Q190A mutant enzymes as well as the WT enzyme exhibited nearly identical amounts of cross-linked radiolabeled template-primer (Fig. 3). This scenario was noted with all of the template-primers, including 26/18-mer combinations, where the photoaffinity group was placed at the +1 and −2 position of the template nucleotide, at the 3′-OH-containing primer nucleotide itself (+1), or at the +4 primer nucleotide position (see Fig. 1). The efficiency of the cross-linking of enzymes to different template-primers was variable, but very little or no change between the WT and two mutant enzymes for the same template-primer was apparent. Therefore, the loss of activity seen with mutant enzymes is not at the level of template-primer binding. The specificity of the cross-linking as being representative of template-primer binding was judged from the following experiments. The cross-linking of all of the above template-primers with all three enzymes was found to be sensitive to the presence of a high ionic strength of the cross-linking medium (>0.3 m) and could be competed out with poly(dC)·(dG)15 but not with poly(dC) or (dG)15 alone (data not shown). Results shown in Fig. 4, A andB, indicate that mutant enzyme-template-primer (RNA·DNA) complexes were inefficient in catalyzing the addition of the complementary nucleotide [α-32P]TTP. The Q190N mutant protein appeared to be the least active, which is consistent with the lowest k cat value noted for this protein. Similar results were obtained when enzymes were linked covalently to azidophenacyl-containing template-primers and assessed for theirin situ nucleotidyltransferase activity (Fig. 4,C–F). The observations that both mutant enzymes exhibit significant reduction in the overall catalytic efficiency for the polymerase reaction, especially with Mg2+, and that a severe impairment in the catalysis of in situnucleotidyltransferase reaction, which qualitatively measures only a single nucleotide addition, strongly indicate the requirement of Gln190 in the conformational change step before the chemical step of the polymerase reaction. Comparative analysis of the rates of incorporation of the individual dNTP and its α-thio derivative was carried out using RNA template. Results indicated that the mutant enzymes utilized dNTPs and their respective α-thio derivatives with similar efficiencies (data not shown). These results rule out the possibility of the defect in the chemical step of phosphodiester bond formation by the mutant polymerase. To probe further the role of Gln190 in the polymerase reaction scheme beyond the steps of initial substrates binding and the bond formation, we determined the rate constants for the first and the second nucleotide addition by the WT and mutant enzymes directed by RNA template.
